title: Lupita Nyong'o reveals she was once told she was 'too dark' to be on television
text:
Lupita Nyong'o has revealed she was once told she was 'too dark' to be on television.

Speaking to Emily Maitlis on BBC's Newsnight, the Oscar-winning actress, 36, detailed the shocking prejudice she encountered during a television audition and discussed her experiences of colourism while growing up in Kenya.

She said: 'I once auditioned for something on TV and I was told I was too dark to be on television.'

Interview: Lupita Nyong'o has revealed she was once told she was 'too dark' to be on television in a new interview

Acclaimed: Speaking to Emily Maitlis on BBC's Newsnight, the Oscar-winning actress, 36, detailed the shocking prejudice she encountered during a television audition (pictured on TV show Shuga)

The acclaimed actress' body of work in television includes Shuga and Star Wars Forces of Destiny.

The Black Panther star also discussed her upbringing in Kenya, and said her younger sister's 'lighter' skintone was praised in a way her skintone was not, as she opened up about colourism - which she branded 'the daughter of racism.'

Colourism is a prejudice against people with a darker skin tone or the preferential treatment of those of the same race but have lighter skin tones.

Nyong'o was raised in Kenya, before moving to the United States.

Spekaing out: The Black Panther star also discussed her upbringing in Kenya, and said her younger sister's 'lighter' skintone was praised in a way her skintone was not

She said: 'I had a younger sister who was born five years after me and she was a lot lighter and she got called pretty and beautiful and all of that.

'She was praised for the lightness of her skin in a way that, I don't recall being praised for the darkness in mine.

'Self-consciously that translates into: 'I'm not worthy'.'

'I definitely grew up feeling uncomfortable with my skin colour because I felt like the world around me awarded lighter skin

'Colourism is born of racism. It is the daughter of racism. And so from a world that rewards lighter skin over darker skin, this then becomes a prejudice among people of the same race.

'So it's the preferential treatment of people with lighter skin and is very, very much linked to racism.'

She said: 'I definitely grew up feeling uncomfortable with my skin colour because I felt like the world around me awarded lighter skin' (pictured in 2018's Black Panther)

She continued: 'Skin colour and race don't necessarily go hand-in-hand. So, for me, as much as I was experiencing colourism in Kenya, I wasn't aware that I belonged to a race called black.

'Which I know is a complex idea because the relationship to my skin was separate from the relationship to my race.'

'Race is a very, very social construct, one that I didn't have to ascribe to on a daily basis growing up regardless of the fact that I was very much a victim of colourism.

'So I think this is the thing about the relationship between race and colourism is that they're related but one of them moved farther away from the other and sometimes we forget how they are related.'

Discussing whether Black Panther had changing the casting experience for black actors, she said: 'I think time will tell whether this has been that pivotal shift. It definitely feels that way.'

The Mexican-born actress is busier than ever these days with her first book, a children's story titled Sulwe out in October and three films out in 2019, including the forthcoming Star Wars flick.

She's also filming thriller 355 with Jessica Chastain and is set to star in The Killer, a remake if John Woo's 1989 classic.

And, writer and director Ryan Coogler recently revealed the next installment of the Black Panther franchise will be released on May 6, 2022.

Lupita plays charming and enigmatic teacher Miss Caroline in the rom-zom-com, Little Monsters which hit limited US theaters on Tuesday for one night only before streaming this Friday on Hulu/Neon.

She shot to worldwide fame when she won an Academy Award for 12 Years A Slave in 2014.
